title: Brexit analysis: Johnson's sleight of hand can't disguise a repackaged bad deal
text:

Magic tricks only work if the audience cannot see how they are done. Boris Johnson will be hoping nobody looks too closely at his sleight of hand yesterday.

The Prime Minister received lots of plaudits for getting the EU to reopen the withdrawal agreement and sign a new deal. Those who just want Brexit done will be grateful he’s got any form of agreement.

Johnson is counting on them not reading the small print.

The way he presented the deal was a masterly piece of showmanship. It disguised the fact he had replaced the Irish backstop with a mechanism that could leave Northern Ireland locked into EU rules for the foreseeable future.

It is far more economically damaging than Theresa May ’s deal (or no Brexit at all) and could see GDP shrink by up to 7% over a decade.

Safeguards on workers’ rights and the environment have been shifted from the withdrawal agreement to the political declaration.

This means they are no longer locked down by treaty and can be swept away by a Tory government. All these factors will matter when MPs vote in the Commons tomorrow.

The DUP are furious at the way Northern Ireland has been annexed and Labour will not vote for anything that hands bosses the whip hand over workers and opens the door to US health firms raiding the NHS.

Johnson’s path to victory relies on the Tory Eurosceptics who sabotaged May’s deal accepting a repackaged version by a fellow Brexiteer.

Even if they fall into line it still leaves him needing the 21 Tory MPs he stripped from the whip and a dozen or so Labour or independents.

Many MPs understand the public’s fatigue with Brexit and could vote for the deal to make the issue go away.

The PM is gambling by assuming that the majority share this view.
description: The Prime Minister has brought a deal back from Brussels that could see GDP shrink by up to 7% over a decade.
